documentType: court filing with appeal and personal statement
summary: This document contains a civil judgment from November 19, 2020, dismissing a case against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction, followed by a notice of appeal and a personal statement from a plaintiff alleging abuse by Maxwell and Epstein. The plaintiff, from the UK, includes claims of bribery with royal items, DNA evidence, and physical injuries.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Named as a defendant in a civil case. The plaintiff alleges meeting her in 2001 in London, being drugged, abused, and receiving items as bribery for silence.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Named as a defendant in a civil case. The plaintiff alleges being stabbed by him, causing physical injury and long-term suffering.

persons.name: Louis L. Stanton
persons.context: Signed the civil judgment dismissing the case for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

persons.name: Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Mentioned in the context of an impact statement submitted to her regarding abuse by the defendants.

persons.name: Paul Burrel
persons.context: Referenced by the plaintiff as the person from whose collection items were allegedly given as bribery for silence, said to be from H.R.H. Prince Andrew.

persons.name: H.R.H. Prince Andrew
persons.context: Allegedly the source, via Paul Burrel, of royal items given to the plaintiff as bribery for silence by Ghislaine Maxwell.

persons.name: H.R.H. Queen Elizabeth II
persons.context: Allegedly recalled giving permission for Paul Burrel to keep Princess Diana's items for safekeeping.

persons.name: Princess Diana
persons.context: Referenced as the original owner of missing items allegedly given as bribery.

connections.description: Named together as defendants in a civil case; plaintiff alleges both were involved in her abuse, drugging, and kidnapping.
Plaintiff alleges Maxwell gave her items said to be from Prince Andrew via Paul Burrel as bribery for silence.
Plaintiff claims Maxwell used items from Paul Burrel's collection (from Princess Diana) as bribery.
Plaintiff states Queen Elizabeth II recalled giving permission for Burrel to keep Princess Diana's items for safekeeping.
Plaintiff alleges Maxwell approached her, drugged her, abused her, and offered bribery for silence.
Plaintiff alleges Epstein stabbed her, causing physical injury and long-term suffering.

events.title: Alleged Initial Meeting and Abuse
events.description: Plaintiff states she first met Ghislaine Maxwell (as 'Marion') in Hyde Park, London, was taken to a home, given a drink, and abused.

events.title: Civil Judgment Dismissal
events.description: U.S. District Judge Louis L. Stanton dismissed the civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.

events.title: Notice of Appeal Filed
events.description: Plaintiff filed a notice of appeal against the dismissal, contesting the grounds and presenting new evidence claims.

events.title: Alleged Ongoing Suffering
events.description: Plaintiff describes 18+ years of physical injury (damaged hip, groin pains), panic attacks, memory issues, nightmares, aggression, arrests, and imprisonment as a result of the alleged abuse.

keyFacts: A civil case against Ghislaine Maxwell and Jeffrey Epstein was dismissed on November 19, 2020, by Judge Louis L. Stanton for lack of subject-matter jurisdiction.
The plaintiff, from the UK, filed an appeal and provided a detailed personal statement alleging she was drugged, kidnapped, abused, and tortured by Maxwell and Epstein starting in 2001.
The plaintiff claims physical evidence including a used condom with Ghislaine Maxwell's DNA, photos of scars from a stabbing by Jeffrey Epstein, and royal items given as bribery for silence.
The bribery items are alleged to be from Princess Diana's missing collection, given via Paul Burrel and said to be from H.R.H. Prince Andrew, with permission recalled from H.R.H. Queen Elizabeth II.

The plaintiff describes severe long-term physical and psychological consequences from the alleged abuse, including a damaged hip, inability to walk properly, panic attacks, memory loss, and imprisonment.
